trigger: Fever cough shortness of breath respiratory symptoms acute onset
strategy: Assess vital signs for evidence of respiratory distress (tachypnea, hypoxemia)
Identify risk factors for common etiologies (smoking, COPD, recent viral exposures, immunocompromise)
Evaluate duration and progression of symptoms (acute vs. chronic, stable vs. worsening)
Examine for localizing signs in lung fields (decreased breath sounds, rales, wheezing)
Stratify by severity using validated tools (CURB-65, PSI for pneumonia; DECAF for COPD)

cautions: Elderly patients and immunocompromised individuals may present atypically without fever
COVID-19 may present with minimal respiratory symptoms but significant hypoxemia ('silent hypoxemia')
Heart failure can mimic or coexist with respiratory infections
Consider pulmonary embolism in patients with risk factors and unexplained tachycardia/hypoxemia
Biomarkers (CRP, procalcitonin) have limited specificity for bacterial infection

example.presentation: 65-year-old male with history of COPD presents with 3 days of fever, productive cough, and worsening shortness of breath. Vital signs show temp 38.5Â°C, HR 110, RR 24, BP 145/85, O2 sat 88% on room air.
example.application: Severity assessment with CURB-65 score of 2 and evidence of COPD exacerbation with likely bacterial pneumonia trigger. Pattern suggests need for blood cultures, sputum analysis, chest imaging, and consideration of combined antibiotics covering both typical and atypical organisms. Hospital admission indicated based on hypoxemia and CURB-65 score.
example.outcome: Patient diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and COPD exacerbation, treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin, supplemental oxygen, and bronchodilators. Improved within 48 hours of admission.
